metadata.titel_preek: Little Resurrections After the Big One
metadata.bijbeltekst: Acts 4:1-12 (referenced as Acts 3-4, though title mentions Psalm 23)

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The Big Resurrection of Jesus unleashes a power that enables the church to perform 'mini-resurrections' (healing/restoration) which challenge the status quo of the Empire.

tekstueel_bewijs: This is the one whom God raised from the dead.
God has unleashed into the world the juices of life.
the big resurrection of Jesus that transforms the world into a venue for life

ontvanger.identificatie: The Lame Beggar / The Marginalized / The Hearer
tekstueel_bewijs: extension of benefits to the unqualified with preexisting conditions
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: Does hearer identify with Subject or Receiver?

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit / The Name of Jesus
tekstueel_bewijs: by the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth
helper.rol_van_god: God is both Subject (Raiser of Jesus) and Helper (Spirit).

tegenstander.identificatie: The Empire / Status Quo / Managers of Money and Power
tekstueel_bewijs: priests, captain of the temple, the Sadducees
the empire of money, power, and control
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is framed as a systemic, political, and economic structure rather than an ontological one (Sin/Death).

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The church performing mini-resurrections as a consequence of the Big Resurrection.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Church/Hearer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The 'Big Resurrection' provides the competence (Pouvoir) for the 'Little Resurrections'.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has unleashed into the world the juices of life.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: The apostles have performed a mini-resurrection.
You also are authorized to perform mini-resurrections.

voorbeelden: They wanted, at all costs, to maintain order.
They no doubt took notes on the teaching.
walking the walk of empowered obedience
the church has power to enact mini-resurrections

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on the 'Power' (Pouvoir) granted by the Resurrection, moving away from 'Must' (Devoir) toward 'Can'.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From S2 (Empire control) to ~S2 (Unauthorized dissent) to S1 (Resurrection life).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by the 'Big Resurrection' which breaks the monopoly of the Empire.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: S2 is treated as a social/political reality rather than a spiritual/eternal one.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is grace-oriented because it grounds human action ('mini-resurrections') entirely in the prior, unmerited act of God ('Big Resurrection').

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: You also are authorized to perform mini-resurrections.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: This is the one whom God raised from the dead.
He was filled with the Holy Spirit, which means he had a surge of energy out beyond explanation.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The apostles are models of 'empowered obedience', but their power is explicitly derived from the Spirit.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Theocentric: God continues to heal through the church as He did through Peter.

identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: The hearer is seen as a participant in God's ongoing work.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The relationship between the 'Big' and 'Little' resurrections is logically and theologically tight.
spanning_punten: The transition from the apostles' specific miracle to the hearer's general 'authorization' is broad.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Easter resurrection is an act that defies the control of the superpower.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is identified with 'money, power, and control' (The Empire) rather than personal guilt.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative engine is driven by God's act (Big Resurrection) which re-tools the human Subject (The Church) to act against the Opponent (The Empire).

subject_herpositionering.huidige_probleem: None; God is clearly the source.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The hearer might feel pressured to 'perform' resurrections.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that the hearer is first the 'lame beggar' before being the 'apostle'.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Include more Savoir (Knowledge of the Gospel content).
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Clarify what a 'mini-resurrection' looks like in daily life beyond metaphor.

tegenstander_intensivering.voorgestelde_intensivering: Internalize the opponent (Sin/Death) to show why human effort alone fails.
tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: To prevent the sermon from becoming a purely political manifesto.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterful example of grounding social ethics in a robust, theocentric narrative of the Resurrection.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'Big/Little' metaphor; Greimas shows how the 'Big' event functions as the Sender of the 'Little' event.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would focus on the historical context of Acts 4; Greimas focuses on the functional roles of Power and Authority.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'Empire' is the necessary Opponent that validates the Subject's new Power.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses 'Empire' as a catch-all for the Opponent, which risks losing the specific theological weight of Sin.
